claim_text: Cyclone Ditwah caused an estimated $4.1 billion in direct physical damage to buildings, agriculture, and critical infrastructure in Sri Lanka.
The death toll from Cyclone Ditwah rose to 607, with 214 people still missing and over 2.08 million affected nationwide.
Over 275,000 children were affected by Cyclone Ditwah, facing an escalating humanitarian crisis due to floods and devastation.
The Sri Lankan government announced compensation of Rs. 5 million for each home destroyed by Cyclone Ditwah-related flooding or landslides.
President Anura Kumara Dissanayake appointed a Presidential Task Force to lead rehabilitation, recovery, and reconstruction efforts in areas affected by Cyclone Ditwah.
India provided over 300 tonnes of humanitarian relief assistance to Sri Lanka under Operation Sagar Bandhu, including rescue, medical support, and essential relief distribution.
The U.S. military deployed C-130J aircraft and logistics teams to assist in delivering critical supplies and support disaster relief efforts in Sri Lanka.
Japan sent a 27-member Disaster Relief Medical Team and provided $1 million worth of shelters through IOM to support recovery efforts after Cyclone Ditwah.
Russia pledged 35 tonnes of humanitarian aid, and Saudi Arabia expressed condolences and support to Sri Lanka following Cyclone Ditwah.
Cyclone Ditwah disrupted communication services, with 80% restored but ongoing disaster conditions slowing full recovery of fibre-optic networks.
Nearly 1,500 bus journeys operated by the Sri Lanka Transport Board were cancelled due to roadblocks caused by Cyclone Ditwah.
The Department of Irrigation began urgent work to restore canals and reservoirs damaged by Cyclone Ditwah to resume water supply to farmlands.
The Asian Development Bank launched a $40 million emergency trade finance facility to aid Sri Lanka’s recovery from Cyclone Ditwah.
The IMF announced the release of a $350 million tranche from its Extended Fund Facility to support post-cyclone relief efforts in Sri Lanka.
Cyclone Ditwah was unusual as it developed near Sri Lanka, approximately 650 km north of the equator, breaking the norm of cyclones forming at least 500 km away.
